item.title: Silksong: Sister Splinter Boss Guide
item.description:
After reaching Shellwood to the left of Bellhart, players must make their way around almost the entire area to wrap back around and find the Sister Splinter boss. Silksong players have had some trouble beating Sister Splinter because of its powerful Triple Slam attack, its ability to summon allies, and moves that block off parts of the boss arena with vines, making it harder to avoid its slam.

If you can learn how to anticipate Sister Splinter's moves, and understand how to effectively avoid its slam while managing the vines and other enemies in the room, you should find a flow to beat this boss without too much hassle.

Follow this guide to learn where to find Sister Splinter in Shellwood, how to beat the Sister Splinter boss in Silksong , and what you will get after downing this freaky root-monster.

Where to Find Sister Splinter in Silksong

Deep Within Shellwood, to the Left of Bellhart

To get to Sister Splinter, you must progress through the lower layers of Shellwood until you reach the far left shaft leading upward. Make your way up, then take the top-right exit to enter a large room that houses a Weaver statue at the very top.

For now, exit the room via a door on the right, platform to the right through the next room, then unlock the elevator shortcut above the central Bench. From the central Bench, take the elevator up and go right, jump and slash flowers to get to the top-left of the next room, then continue left until Sister Splinter appears.

Optimal Sister Splinter Runback Route & Closest Bench

The best Bench for the Sister Splinter fight is the central bench in Shellwood, which connects to the elevator shortcut you should unlock on the way to the Sister Splinter boss fight. You can unlock this Bench earlier in the zone for a steep 60 Rosaries.

Take the elevator up, exit to the right, then make your way around the room in the far top-right of the zone until you reach two white flowers leading to the top-left exit (above the entrance to the room). Downward slash onto these flowers to get across, then keep going left to safely get back to Sister Splinter.

Complete Sister Splinter Boss Walkthrough

How to Beat Sister Splinter in Silksong

Sister Splinter Moveset, Attacks, & Counters

Attack Image

Move Name

Visual Cues

Counter

Triple Slam

Raises one arm briefly before slamming down in a slightly diagonal arc. Alternates between left and right three times.

Dodge in the opposite direction of the slam â€“ if its right hand is active, dodge to the left. Dodge the two follow-up slams the same way.

This is Sister Splinter's primary attack. When it summons thorny vines that block off the room, it can be incredibly difficult to avoid without taking damage from something. Use Silkspear (or break the vines with your Needle) to create more room to dodge away.

Summon Ally

Sister Splinter roars, then retreats into the ceiling. Up to two spaces on the wall light up, indicating the location where flying allies will spawn. These enemies can fly through thorns.

Attack the boss as it roars, you can get about 4 or 5 hits in during this animation. Use Tools and the Silkspear ability to dispatch the flying enemies as fast as you can.

Summon Thorn Vines

Retreats into the ceiling, then a beam will indicate the direction a long thorny vine will launch into the floor. These vines take three hits to break, and multiple can be summoned at once.

If there are only one or two thorn vines, simply hit them with your needle to break them and free up more space in the boss arena.

If there are more than two, consider using Silkspear to break multiple at once and save some time (though you will have to wait longer to Bind and heal).

Multi-Thorns

Retreats into the ceiling, then six beams will appear across the top of the room. After a moment, thorn vines will launch into the ground from the outside in, severely limiting the amount of space Hornet has to maneuver. As Hornet breaks vines, more will take their place.

Move between two of the beams to avoid taking damage from the thorns, then use Silkspear to break multiple vines at once instantly.

Sister Splinter Boss Tips & Tricks

  • If you do not have enough Silk to cast Silkspear during the room-blanketing Multi-Thorn attack, get to the center of the room, then rapidly hit the two thorns on both sides when they appear.
    • After clearing the middle space, go toward one wall and hit vines on the way. Though vines will respawn as you destroy them at first, they will stop respawning after about three waves.
    • Make sure you clear at least three thorn vines worth of space to have room to dodge the slam.

  • Traps and Tools that can damage enemies in mid-air are practically essential for the parts of the fight when a flying ally appears.
    • Foe example, the Longpin is thrown in an arc like a spear, and can hit both Sister Splinter and any flying enemies at the top of the arc, even if they are near the ceiling out of Hornet's normal reach.
    • Tools are also incredibly useful for dealing with the Multi-Thorn attack. Longpin will pierce through vines in its way. Spam this Tool to quickly break multiple vines at once (if you have enough Tool ammo to spam it, that is).

  • If you can time your dodges well, you can jump up and attack Sister Splinter in between each of its slam attacks , netting a handful of additional hits during this move.

What Happens After Beating Sister Splinter in Silksong?

After you beat Sister Splinter, Silksong players will unlock access to the rest of Shellwood. Most notably, the exit to the left of the boss arena leads to the top half of another room Hornet ventured through earlier. Make your way around the central pillar and you will find a weaver statue.

Bind in front of this statue to get the Cling Grip ability. This is an extremely useful movement ability for Hornet as it allows her to grab onto vertical surfaces and wall jump. Getting the Cling Grip ability allows players to continue through Shellwood to the Widow fight to save Bellhart, but you can also return to old zones to explore previously-inaccessible areas with this skill.

Hollow Knight: Silksong
12
9.8 /10
Released
September 4, 2025

item.title: How to Complete the Radio Tower Easter Egg in Warzone
item.description:
Call of Duty: Warzone took players back to good old Verdansk in Season 3, much to the excitement of those looking to relive the glory days of Call of Duty's popular Battle Royale game. Now that the map has been back for a while, players have uncovered a great deal of secrets and Easter Eggs.

While a small portion of these Easter Eggs yield secret Blueprint rewards, others award something completely different. As of Season 5 Reloaded, players can now activate radio towers as part of another side Easter Egg, one that allows them to tell if other players are nearby. Here is how to complete the Radio Tower Easter Egg in Warzone .

Step #1: Head to the Control Tower Complex & Find the Terminal

For the first step, players will need to head over to the Control Tower Complex (located on the north side of the Airport). Here, you can find a terminal next to a radar dish that showcases 10 different radio towers scattered throughout Verdansk. The key is to take note of which radio towers are offline , indicated by the red negative sign. Two will be offline in each game, though the specific towers will differ from match to match.

Once done, you are free to move on to the next step.

Step #2: Activate the Radio Towers Shown on the Terminal

For the second and final step, players will need to activate the two offline radio towers shown on the terminal. These radio towers can be found all around Verdansk, with their numbers displayed on the side of the tower before heading up. At the top of each tower, players will find a switch that, once interacted with, will activate the radio tower. This process needs to be repeated for both towers.

There are a total of 10 radio towers across Verdansk , each in fixed locations around the map. In our case, we had to head to both Tower 08 and Tower 09 and activate them, which are located northwest of the Hospital and far west of the Train Station. However, the towers you need to visit may differ, so be sure to check the locations provided in the image above to find the ones you must activate.

Once both towers are active, the Easter Egg is complete. While players will not be given loot or a special cosmetic reward, they will instead gain the ability to see the threat level of each major POI when entering it , alerting them if players are within the vicinity.

Call of Duty: Warzone
9 /10
52
7.7 /10
Released
March 10, 2020

item.title: Silksong: How to Get the Reaper Crest
item.description:
Crests in Hollow Knight: Silksong change how Hornet 's attacks work and also have different tool slots. This means that when players acquire a new Crest, they will have to unlock all the slots on the new crest, even if they had unlocked the slots on their old crest.

As Crests significantly change the combat and platforming, players must acquire all of them to determine what works best for them. The Crest of the Reaper is a Crest that players can find a few hours into Hollow Knight: Silksong , and the location is mentioned in the guide below.

How to Get the Reaper Crest in Silksong

To get the Crest, players must first progress through the game until they reach Greymoor , which is a main story location. Once you arrive at this location, turn left, going towards the Halfway Home Bench . Make sure to interact with this bench , as you will be using this bench quite a lot when exploring the whole of the area and running back to the boss room.

From the Halfway Home bench, head left again , and you will have an encounter. Deal with the enemies so that you can leave the room and continue left. Ignore the enemies standing outside and head further left into the tower. Now your goal is to go even further left, but you can't do that right now since the door is locked. Instead, go up the tower, stick to the left side so you can exit, and drop all the way down to the lever , which will open the gate.

Doing this makes it so you don't have to climb the tower again when revisiting this place.

Now, to the bottom left of this large room is a hole that leads down to the Moorwing boss arena, so you can ignore that for now. Instead, head towards the middle section on the left . You will have to climb up some platforms, and you can head inside to find the Chapel of the Reaper .

Chapel of the Reaper in Silksong

The Chapel of the Reaper is not lengthy by any means, but there is an encounter that might be difficult depending on when you are visiting this Chapel to acquire the Crest. First, drop down and head right to where you will spot a moving wheel, which is making spiked cogs move alongside it. You need to jump and dash towards the platforms and go further up without getting hit by the cogs, as they will deal damage to you. You can down Pogo on these spiky cogs , but it is not recommended, especially if you have the starting Crest equipped.

Once you reach the platform above, you will have to fight a bunch of enemies that will spawn one or two at a time. This section can be annoying, but the enemies are all those you have previously encountered, so you might have an idea how to deal with them. Once the encounter is finished, head up to find a body that you can press the Bind button on . This will reward you with the Reaper Crest , and its description states that it allows you to attack with heavy, arcing slashes and reap additional Silk from enemies .

  • This crest has two Red , two Yellow , and two Blue Tool Slots same as the starting crest.

item.title: If Indiana Jones and the Great Circle Was a Love Letter to Raiders of the Lost Ark, its DLC is a Love Letter to The Last Crusade
item.description:
This article contains MAJOR SPOILERS for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle and Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants .

Though it was inspired by classic Westerns, James Bond movies, and even Scrooge McDuck comic strips, Raiders of the Lost Ark itself is one of the most influential action-adventure movies of all time. There have been countless homages to Raiders ' iconic opening, its thrilling car chase, and its haunting climax over the years, but one of the best love letters came in the form of last year's Indiana Jones and the Great Circle , an overt passion project by developer MachineGames.

While Indiana Jones and the Great Circle tells its own original story, it contains plenty of nods to the adventurer's first silver screen outing. The 2024 game begins with a recreation of Raiders of the Lost Ark 's Peru temple raid, its second major level takes Indy back to Egypt, and the overarching plot sees him racing a band of Nazis to retrieve an artifact of religious importance. Indiana Jones and the Great Circle isn't afraid to wear its Raiders influences on its sleeve, but its recently released DLC spends much of its runtime revering another Indiana Jones movie.

Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants Feels Like a Love Letter to The Last Crusade

The Order of Giants Explores A Familiar Location

Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade sees the titular hero going in search of his missing father, who disappeared while searching for the Holy Grail. Indy's adventure kicks off in Venice, where he finds an ancient catacomb hidden underneath the Biblioteca di San Barnaba. This dimly lit network of underground stone caverns eventually leads to the tomb of Sir Richard, one of the knights of the First Crusade who's said to have found the Holy Grail.

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's The Order of Giants DLC follows in The Last Crusade 's footsteps very closely. This story DLC sees Indy leaving the confines of the Vatican and exploring the waterways and sewers of Rome. During the course of the 3â€“4 hour adventure, players will find themselves walking through very similar environments to those used in The Last Crusade 's Venice sequence, with stone-lined catacombs and rat-filled sewers being common settings in the DLC.

Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants even has Indy popping up from a sewer manhole at one point, which is reminiscent of the scene in The Last Crusade where Indy and Elsa exit the sewer and end up on the busy streets of Venice's Piazza San Marco.

The Order of Giants Expolores a Familiar Mythology

Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants ' story focuses on three members of the Nephilim Order, a secret organization of "giants" who have been tasked with protecting the keys to a religious artifact. Already, this concept of a secret organization protecting an item of religious significance feels like an homage to The Last Crusade 's Brotherhood of the Cruciform Sword. But the similarities stretch further.

Those who have completed Indiana Jones and the Great Circle 's story will know that this religious artifact is actually Noah's Ark, which uses the Nephilim-protected keys to open up a portal to different sites around the globe. It's mentioned in The Great Circle that it might not be Noah's Ark specifically, as there have been many great floods throughout mythology and history, but the Bible is referenced frequently during the game.

The Order of Giants' story continues the base game's exploration of Christianity. One of the aforementioned Nephilim giants the DLC revolves around is the 'Nameless Crusader', a soldier sent to obtain one of the Noah's Ark keys from the city of Antioch under the guise of helping the Crusade's war effort. The Nameless Crusader's tragic life is detailed via one of The Order of Giants' tomb puzzles, which looks and feels like an unused Last Crusade sequence thanks to its similar use of stark, white lighting, its stone architecture, and its Christian/Crusader imagery.

The Order of Giants Even Has a Similar Third Act Twist

To top the homage off, Indiana Jones: The Order of Giants even features a similar third act twist with its villain. In Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade , Indy is hired by Walter Donovan to find his missing father and his diary. After recovering the diary and using it to find the starting location for the hunt for the Holy Grail, Indy is betrayed by Donovan, who's revealed to be working with the Nazis.

The Order of Giants begins with a Vatican priest named Father Ricci tasking Indy with uncovering the secrets of the Nephilim Order tombs. After retrieving the artifacts from each tomb, Indy is betrayed by Father Ricci, who reveals himself to be the leader of a cult operating underneath Rome.

item.title: 4 Xbox Game Pass Games to Play This Week (September 7 - September 13)
item.description:
September can feel like a reset button for gaming. The summer release rush has cooled, the holiday season hasnâ€™t quite kicked into gear, and players are left with a rare mix of heavy-hitters and sleeper picks to explore. Itâ€™s the perfect moment to dive into games that demand time, whether itâ€™s an epic new release or a cozy sim that pairs well with the seasonâ€™s slower pace. And Xbox Game Pass offers players the perfect ground to explore this space.

This week on Game Pass, players can strike the perfect balance. Thereâ€™s the long-awaited sequel that fans have been clamoring for, a co-op title guaranteed to spark drama on the couch, a stylish cult hit that rewards curiosity, and a fan-favorite farming sim that feels tailor-made for the early days of fall. Whether youâ€™re looking for intensity, comfort, or something to share with friends, this lineup covers every mood.

Hollow Knight: Silksong

If you're a Metroidvania fan and havenâ€™t jumped on the hype yet, Iâ€™m not sure what youâ€™re waiting for. But take this weekâ€™s top recommendation as a sign to download Hollow Knight: Silksong on Game Pass. By now, there should hopefully be no platform collapsing at the sheer demand for this long-awaited indie title. Therefore, I hope youâ€™re able to download this title as quickly as possible.

As a sequel to one of the most beloved indie games of all time, Silksong carries impossibly high expectations. And it somehow lives up to them with its incredibly haunting environment and surprisingly challenging learning curve. Some of the differences between Hollow Knight and Silksong include expanded movement options, improved combat depth, and new biomes. All of these bring fresh challenges without losing the precision and atmosphere that made Hollow Knight so environmentally iconic. For fans of Metroidvanias and exploration in gaming, Silksong should be a no-brainer. Itâ€™s rare for a game to dominate the spotlight this completely, but Silksong and Team Cherry more than earned it.

A Way Out

As a con-goer preparing to spend a lot of time socializing with friends after long convention days over Labor Day weekend, I needed to pick a game that could entertain everyone. Instead of opting for well-known couch co-op favorites, I pitched in a title that would stir the pot just a little bit more than most. And I am so proud that I was able to cause full-on shouting matches thanks to A Way Out.

Split Fiction and It Takes Two fans will immediately recognize A Way Outâ€™s formula. After all, it was developed by Hazelight Studios. But what sets this one apart is its gritty narrative about two escaped convicts who rely on one another to survive. Unlike many lighthearted co-op titles, A Way Out pushes players to make tough calls, and that tension makes for some truly unforgettable moments.

Control: Ultimate Edition

If Silksong is the headline grabber and A Way Out is the grim party-starter, Control: Ultimate Edition is the game that sneaks up on players with style. Remedy Entertainmentâ€™s award-winning supernatural action game thrives on mood, setting, and mystery, drawing players into the Federal Bureau of Controlâ€™s shifting headquarters, the Oldest House.

With the Ultimate Edition on Game Pass, the experience is at its most complete. Both Control expansions are included, and the extras serve as additional boons for players to enjoy. The result is a sharp, stylish action game that blends eerie worldbuilding with dynamic gameplay. For anyone looking to spend some nights lost in atmosphere and questions, Control still delivers one of the most original gaming experiences of the last decade.

Stardew Valley

As fall begins and temperatures drop with the start of school, sometimes, all you need is a cozy thing or activity to unwind. Bonus points if that activity fits the fall vibe. From enjoying a cup of hot cocoa to reading, there are plenty of activities that can help you tick off that box. But for gamers, Stardew Valley is the ideal game to quiet the chaos of a busy day. And with Stardew Valley â€™s 1.7 update recently announced, nowâ€™s the best time to get into the gameâ€™s rhythms.

What makes Stardew special isnâ€™t just its farming sim mechanics, but the way the game quietly becomes about building routines, relationships, and a sense of community. Every season feels different, and fall in particular makes the game shine with its orange-hued palette, slower pace, and Stardew Valley â€™s best festivals. Whether youâ€™re putting in 20 minutes before bed or losing hours to fishing and mining, Stardew Valley remains one of Game Passâ€™s most comforting staples.
